title: Leash & Greetings
summary: Introduce harness gear, loose-leash patterns, and calm social scripts before the teen stage hits.

lessons.title: Harness Happy Dance
lessons.objective: Teach puppies to step into gear voluntarily.
steps: Show the harness, feed through the head hole to create a treat tunnel.
Hold the harness low; mark and reward any nose poke or paw step.
Once confident, cue through and clip while feeding continuously.
Remove harness calmly, give a short play break, and repeat.
supportGuidelines: Coach families to avoid chasing the puppy with the harness.
Encourage pairing harness time with sniff walks so it predicts fun.
Log fit adjustments to ensure no rubbing as the puppy grows.
lessons.safetyNotes: Check for two-finger spacing each session to prevent chafing.

lessons.title: Indoor Loose-Leash Figure Eights
lessons.objective: Rehearse leash skills without outdoor distractions.
steps: Clip leash and stand between two cones placed eight feet apart.
Walk in a figure-eight pattern, marking every two loose steps.
When the leash tightens, plant feet and wait for slack before moving again.
Gradually speed up and slow down to teach puppies to mirror your pace.
supportGuidelines: Coach handlers to keep hands low at the hips to avoid reeling in.
Remind them to feed at their pant seam so the puppy stays aligned.
Suggest practicing before meals to boost treat motivation.
lessons.safetyNotes: Watch for leash chewing—swap to a tug toy if puppies get mouthy.

lessons.title: Calm Greeting Protocol
lessons.objective: Teach puppies to sit politely before saying hi to people.
steps: Set the puppy on a mat facing you while the helper approaches.
Cue sit; if the puppy stays seated, allow the helper to pet briefly.
If the puppy pops up, the helper turns away while you reset and cue sit again.
Reward with treats and praise when the puppy maintains composure for three seconds.
supportGuidelines: Coach helpers to stay calm—no squealing or fast hands.
Remind families to advocate for their puppy in public by delaying greetings until the sit happens.
Encourage journaling tough environments (lobby, park) for future field trips.
lessons.safetyNotes: Stop the session if the puppy shows fear—switch helpers or add more distance.
